''Entoloma madidum'' }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Entoloma bloxamii'' | whichGills = adnexed | capShape = depressed | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=bare | sporePrintColor=pink | howEdible=unknown | howEdible2=caution}} '''''Entoloma bloxamii''''', commonly known as the '''big blue pinkgill''' or '''Bloxam's entoloma''', is a mushroom in the [[Entolomataceae]] family of [[fungi]]. It is widely distributed in Europe, although it is rare throughout its range, which also extends into Asia and North America. {{cite web|url=http://www.artdata.slu.se/Bern_Fungi/ECCF%2033_T-PVS%20(2001)%2034%20rev_low%20resolution_p%2015-82.pdf|title=Compiled information for the suggested fungi |year=2001|work=Threatened Fungi in Europe|publisher=European Council for Conservation of Fungi (ECCF)|accessdate=31 July 2011}} ==Taxonomy== First named ''Agaricus bloxami'' by [[Miles Joseph Berkeley]] and Broome in 1854, in honour of [[Andrew Bloxam]], it was given its current name by the Italian mycologist [[Pier Andrea Saccardo]] in 1887. It was also known as ''E. madidum'' in the United States.{{cite book|author=William C. Roody|title=Mushrooms of West Virginia and the Central Appalachians|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|year=2003|pages=276|isbn=0-8131-9039-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5HGMPEiy4ykC&pg=PA276&dq=Entoloma+bloxamii&hl=en&ei=eT01TvupBerSmAXsoajwCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Entoloma%20bloxamii&f=false}} ''Entoloma bloxamii'' belongs to the large genus ''Entoloma'', which contains around 1500 species worldwide. A 2009 study analysing [[DNA sequence]]s and spore [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] found it to lie in a prunuloides [[clade]] with (among other species) ''[[Entoloma gelatinosum|E. gelatinosum]]'' and ''[[Entoloma cretaceum|E. cretaceum]]'', and most closely related to ''[[Entoloma prunuloides|E. prunuloides]]''. This rhodopolioid clade lay within a crown ''Entoloma'' clade. This group is typified by irregular spores with or without bumps.{{cite journal |year=2009 |last=Co-David |first1=D |last2=Langeveld |first2=D |last3=Noordeloos |first3=ME |title=Molecular phylogeny and spore evolution of Entolomataceae |journal=Persoonia |pmid=20198166 |volume=23 |pmc=2802732 |pages=147–76 |doi=10.3767/003158509X480944 |url=http://www.entoloma.nl/pdf/Co-David_et_al_entolomataceae.pdf |format=PDF |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724152641/http://www.entoloma.nl/pdf/Co-David_et_al_entolomataceae.pdf |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df=dmy }} Common names in the United Kingdom include "big blue pinkgill" and "Bloxam's entoloma". The [[British Mycological Society]] has recommended phasing out the latter in favour of the former as the official name.{{cite web |url=http://www.fungi4schools.org/Reprints/ENGLISH_NAMES.pdf |title=Recommended English Names for Fungi in the UK |format=PDF |publisher=[[British Mycological Society]] |accessdate=11 October 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716083053/http://www.fungi4schools.org/Reprints/ENGLISH_NAMES.pdf |archive-date=16 July 2011 |url-status=dead }} It is known as the midnight blue entoloma in North America. ==Description== The fungus produces a striking, blue, mushroom-shaped [[epigeous]] (aboveground) [[fruiting body]] (basidiocarp), between August and November. The smooth [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] has a broad swelling in the centre (known as a boss or [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]]), which has a more violet tinge. The tightly packed, white [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] on the underside of the cap contrast well with the blue colour of the fungus; they develop a more salmon-pink colour as they age.{{cite web|url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/entoloma_bloxami.html|title= Entoloma bloxami|last=Kuo|first=Michael|year=2008|work=MushroomExpert.Com Web site|accessdate=13 August 2011}} The solid [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] of the mushroom is also blue in colour with a whitish base. The [[spore print]] is pink to cinnamon-coloured.{{cite book |author=Arora, David |authorlink=David Arora |title=Mushrooms Demystified: a Comprehensive Guide to the Fleshy Fungi |publisher=Ten Speed Press |location=Berkeley, California |year=1986 |page=243 |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} ==Distribution and habitat== It is widely distributed in western Europe from Spain and the British Isles east to Poland and Ukraine, as well as Scandinavia in the north and Italy to the southeast, although it is rare throughout its range, which also extends into Asia and North America. It inhabits unimproved grasslands such as old meadows and hayfields. It is usually associated with [[Calcareous grassland|calcareous soils]] although it may also be found in more acidic areas,Courtecuisse, R. & Duhem, B. (1995) Mushrooms and toadstools of Britain and Europe. Harper Collins, London. and is threatened by the disturbance of its habitat caused by agricultural improvement. As of June 2003, it was a candidate species for listing in Appendix I of the [[Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats]] (the "Bern Convention").The distribution, status and habitat requirement of the 33 fungal candidates for listing in Appendix I of the Bern Convention (June 2003) http://www.artdata.slu.se/Bern_Fungi/Bern_Fungi.htmBern Convention (June, 2003) http://www.nature.coe.int/english/cadres/bern.htm {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040603033857/http://www.nature.coe.int/english/cadres/bern.htm |date=3 June 2004 }} ==Edibility== It has a nondescript taste and smell. Its edibility in eastern North America is not known but many members of the genus are poisonous.
